bboxes.raw_text:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. South
ern segregationists are saying
what their representatives said
in 1887, that the matter of human
rights-Negro human rights, that
isis one for the states, not for
the Federal government"
NAACP Executive Secretary Roy
Wilkins told Harvard men in an
address at Quincy House dinner
Getting.


In his Quincy House address,
Mr.. wilkins warned that the Ne
gro "can be expected to react
strongly to Congressional denial
of his oneness with the rest of
humankind if the public accom-
modations section of the pending
civil rights bill is impaired.


Denial of equal access to public
accommodations. he said, is an
affront to (the Negro 81 humanity
...no longer bearable."


MIR. wilkins traced the devel-
opment of the southern way of
life' and cited the impact of the

WILKINS SAYS NEGRO RIGHTS
ARE MOST IMPORTANT NOW

US. Supreme Court anti-segre-
cation rulings on the Southern
Establishment.


"Racial segregation under the
Constitution was groggy in 1854"
he said. "The thing that brought
about BROWN (the school deseg-
regation decision) was not Chief
Justice Earl Warren or any of
the other favorite whipping boys;
it was the slow, but memorable
march of free men down century
fos striving in a national eli
mate and in a changing world
whice gave moral blessing to
their struggle.


eff in 1854 the South lost the
basis of its society, then that
basis is we'll lost, for no people
is made great by reliance upon
SO mean and lowly a dogma as
skin color and the accompanying
societal contrivances and decep-
lively comforting myths that blot
out, now and again, the unlovely
realities"

WASHINGTON The Supreme
Court let stand decision bar
ring racial segregation in hos
pitals built with help of federal
funds.


This action could end segre-
CATION in hospitals in the South.


The decision involves around
the 1916 Halliburton Act which
supports state hospital construc-
ton programs with federal funds.


In 1862. ii Negro doctors.
dentists and patients in Green's
boro. NC, filed a suit against
Wesley Long Community. and
Moses H. Cone hospitals.


They asked for an antisegre-
cation order along with the re-
lection of the Separate but
equal facilities provision that
was written into the Halliburton
Act.


The circuit court ruled that the
hospitals would have to admit
Negro doctors to staff positions
and provide unsegregated facil-
tiles for Negro patients.

HOSPITAL RULING
IS BLOW TO SOUTH

Second half of 1868 taxes are
payable now County Treasurer
John Foote reported.


Taxpayers have nine weeks
to pay the remaining half of last
years tax bill before it becomes
delinquent on May 4.


Payment may be mailed to
County Treasurer, P. o. Box
6410, Phoenix 85OO5, or over the
counter at 1925 w. Durango.
Foote assured taxpayers his staff
will give prompt service either
way.


Residents are reminded they
will not be billed for their second
half taxes. Checks should be &C
companied by a receipt of the
first half payment. If the re-
ceipt has been lost, taxpayers
amy call the County Treasurer's
Office, AL 8-96ll, for the amount
due.


Delinquent taxes are assessed
a ten percent interest penalty
prorated monthly on the unpaid
balance.

Whitney M. Young, Jr.. exc
cutive director of the National
Urban League. will address the
10Th annual meeting of the Phoe-
nix Urban League Fri. March
20, $50 pm at the Safari Ho-
tel in Scottsdale.


Young is one of the nations
most dynamic and effective lead
ers in interracial relations. The
St. Louis Post-Dispatch stated
that he "...has put the National
Urban League in the forefront
of those who are urging special
compensatory programs to make
up for the disadvantages Amer
lean Negroes have suffered for
so many years.


''He also has brought new
sense of urgency to the League.
Perhaps the most professional
but least demonstrative of civil
rights groups, the 54-year-old.
organization specializes in job
training and social welfare"


Young, 43 has been his pres
ent position since October, 1861.
Prior to that time he was Dean
of the School of Social Work at
Atlanta University. He received
his bachelor degree from Ken
lucky State College at the age
of Is, received his masters
degree in social work from the
University of MINES ota. and was
given an honorary doctorate by
North Carolina A. & T. College.


He has been a Visiting Schol-
ar at Harvard, recipient of the
Lasker Award for outstanding
achievement in social work and of
the Outstanding Alumnus Award
from the University of MINES ota.
A frequent White House visitor,
Young has been advisor to a
number of committees in the Ken
nedy administration as well as
to many universities and social
work agencies.

Samuel Dewitt Proctor, one of
the nations leading Negro edu-
Gators, will return to the Peace
Corps in the key position of
Associate Director for Volun-
teers, Peace Corps Director Sar-
gent Shriver announced.


eve can consider ourselves
fortunate that we we're able to
persuade man of DR.. Proctor's
abilities to come back to US
especially to a position in which
he himself set many of the pol
icies," Shriver said.


AS associate director for VOL
unteers, the 42-year-old Proctor
will supervise the selection of
prospective volunteers from
among the applicants and direct
their training.


He will assume his duties on
March %, upon resignation leave
as President of North Carolina
Agricultural and Technical Col
lege, Greensboro, NC.

Seven Negroes have held the
worlds heavyweight boxing title.
l. Jack Johnson Dec. 26,
1908 = Apr. S, 1915.
2. Joe Louis June %, 1887
March p, l949 (retired)
3. Ezzard Charles June %,
l949- July Is, 1851.
4. Joe Walcott- July lS. 1851
Sept. 1852.

S. Floyd Patterson-Nov. 80,


1856 June 70, 1859; June,


lo60-Sept. 1862.


E. Sonny Liston-Sept. 1862


Feb. 1864.


7. Cassius Clay-Feb. 1864.
According to the record books
Joe Louis defended his title a
total of Is times, more than any
other champion.

Bidding farewell nationally known evangelist officers
of the Church O God association.


left Mrs. Mary Huchings state president; Mrs.
Riley Panhandle Texas assistant director of the Ma
tonal Scholarship Counci Crockett Ford evangelist
Chicago Mrs. Ruby Stuart 1884 W. Cocoah hostess and
president.


revival the House of Prayer
Church of God in Christ Elder George John
is the church pastor.


Choirs from Winsow Flagstaff and Tucson participated in
grand musical program Saturday night

The second Coronation Ball held
Eks Lodge #477 Sat-


Narraors Grand District Deputy Maple L. Pratt and
Williams.


<Shown Roscoe Patterson, exalted ruler,
Bible bearer, Arneta Burton
Backhear presents CROWN Esther McEroy Ball
Queen, Grand Dist Deputy James McEoy Letha Ross,
Lisa


Mrs. McEroy received the award for her outstanding
service and contribution Grand Canyon Temple 437, Eks
Hary unit
